ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the historical foundations of Buddhism, the core Buddhist beliefs, and how different "branches" of Buddhism arose from the original beliefs (mostly "foundational Buddhism," a little bit of Tibetan Buddhism, Mahayana, and Vinayana). I learned how to break down and analyze historical Buddhist texts (different sutras; Lotus Sutra, Diamond Sutra, Heart Sutra) and connect them with logical/philosophical arguments.
Conversational understanding of Buddhist thought and history.
The stories, metaphors, big ideas that Buddhism is comprised of; how to interpret a "religious" passage
We learned about Buddhist foundations and Mahayana Buddhism, as well as how to interpret the world through a Buddhist view
The foundations of Buddhist thought.
This class taught the foundational concepts of Buddhism and functions as a great intersectional study of religion and philosophy.
I learned about the key ideas of foundational and Mahayana Buddhism. I learned about how Buddhism deals with certain contradictions.
Buddhist philosophy, key buddhist terms, how buddhism evovled over time...

The course starts with the very beginnings of Buddhism in ancient India, introducing the early Buddhist teachings of the four noble truths, non-self, dependent arising, karma, and more. It ends with how these Buddhist teachings evolved hundreds of years after the Buddha's death.
Learned about foundational Buddhist history and spirituality. Very helpful and a great introduction to the religion.
Fundamental Buddhist beliefs and where they stem from. Got to read from primary Buddhist texts, and learned SO much about Buddhism as a religion and culture.
A lot of knowledge on Buddhist teaching styles
thinking outside the box
I developed a strong fundamental understanding of Buddhist thought from multiple different perspectives

I learned so much. It felt like my life was swept up by the exciting material of this course. I learned so much. This class was super interested to take having had very little exposure to non-commercialized Buddhism.
History and foundations of Buddhism
I learned about the foundations of buddhism and the philosophies of buddhist thought.
I learned about the philosophy of Buddhism and its origins while engaging with an abundance of primary texts about the Buddha's journey
Learned more about the history and details of the Buddhist tradition.
A better understanding of Buddhist Thought
I learned about the history of Buddhism

I learned extensively about the foundations of traditional Buddhist thought as well as the basis of Mahayana Buddhism and the philosophical questions that arise from the Buddhist thoughts and practices.

I developed a better understanding of foundational Buddhist concepts and how they fit into larger Buddhist practice. Definitely the skill to really get deep into specific texts and find important connections between sources.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths are the lectures and the sections, where the ideas from the lecture are reinforced and strengthened. In general, this class was quite low stress, which helped make the learning more enjoyable (after all, we experience enough dukkha anyways). No particular weaknesses come to mind.
Perhaps this can't be fixed, but some of the readings were extremely boring.
Great course, and the order in which each topic was taught fed really well into the next one. No weaknesses
Strengths: easy A if you put in the work, and very interesting. No glaring weaknesses.
A 10 page paper and a final in a lecture is a lot.

This course was great and super interesting there is nothing I would change. The material is sometimes confusing but that's because Professor Greene is choosing what to teach because not everything can be taught on the subject.

Professor Greene is great. His lectures are engaging, well-organized, and clear.  Professor Greene also is willing to answer any questions (very approachable) and even set up a meeting if his office hours don't work for you.
Weakness: A lot of people are taking this course because of the low workload, and that makes discussion section less engaging.
Great class. The lectures were super engaging. Enough assignments to keep you on top of the material, but it was never overwhelming.

Professor Greene is an engaging lecturer, and he fits a good amount of content in fifty minute classes, keeping me focused during class. I wish the class covered how some of these Buddhist ideas are put into practice a little more, as we did not do a lot of that.
I found the lectures fun and humorous, Prof. Greene is a skillful educator and occasionally asked profound questions that made us really think.

Amazing class. Because there were no assignments besides the exams and paper, I felt completely stress-free about the course and came to class super engaged in the lectures and topics. I knew that I was learning out of sheer interest, and not because I had to learn to complete a pset.

strength = very interesting
weakness = a bit boring

I think it is structured well with great TA's which encouraged engagement in section. The assessments were well considered to encourage learning of concepts, whilst allowing the student to dictate level of commitment/engagement, which I think is a great characteristic for a course.

Strengths: Prof. Greene is great, I had an amazing TA who was really helpful with questions related to paper topics/study tips. 

Weaknesses: students often didn't talk during discussion sections
Good lectures
This class was very well organized.

Strength - Great Professor, he is obviously super passionate about Buddhist. literature and made lectures enjoyable
Weakness - I don't think the TAs were very good; in fact, they graded a bit too harshly and unevenly in my opinion which I found a bit unfair.
The course was well organized and it was clear what the expectations were for assignments. The lectures were interesting but readings were sometimes pretty lengthy.
I liked the sections a lot, and the tests. The essay was a little challenging

I think Professor Greene did a fantastic job of providing well-structured, organized lectures and accompanying our classes with helpful readings. Additionally, he made it very easy to study for exams by providing clear cut guidelines with what we could expect.

Variety in the readings was a big strength of this course for me. There was a healthy mix of primary and secondary texts which helped with comprehension. There were also some documentaries mixed in which a nice way to break things up occasionally. Lectures are very much based in the texts so can sometimes get a bit dry, but Prof. Greene often points out interesting questions or contradictions which definitely reward paying attention.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely. The lectures/readings/sections were quite laid back but very informative and helped to reinforce core ideas of Buddhist thought. The grading is very reasonable, and the workload is not too much so long as you don't fall behind on lectures or push your paper until the last minute.
Fun, interesting course for those curious about Buddhist thought.

Yes! Especially if you are interested in philosophy or Buddhist thought. Some of the topics were quite eye-opening for me and made me understand the world and my own culture a bit differently. Might be quite a few terms that you are unfamiliar with or might have trouble memorizing, but as long as your show up to lecture consistently, you'll catch on. Would be hard to follow the course without showing up to lecture!
Yes! It was really interesting throughout (if you care about Buddhist philosophy), and grading was not very difficult.
Sure, it is easy enough.
Yes it was a super interesting change of pace.

If you are looking for a relatively easy and interesting class, then yes. Buddhism is interesting, and Professor Greene is a good lecturer. If you go to class, you'll have some fun and learn interesting stuff. But a lot of people take the class just because it easy, and that makes discussion section less engaging.

The material was really interesting and I learned a lot about Buddhism but the class still felt chill. I felt like I could keep up by listening to lectures without doing the readings. Coming from a STEM major, this was one of my favorite classes at Yale and complemented my other classes quite well. The quiz and exams were reasonable, graded nicely, and required studying but nothing beyond 5-10 hours. We are also given the terms and passages to know ahead of time, which helps narrow the scope of the exams. We also had a 2,000 word essay where we could choose one of a few prompts.

YES! One of my favorite Yale classes. If you have any interest in religion or buddhism, you have to take this class. The lectures are so engaging and interesting, and it's a low workload. You'll learn a decent amount without being stressed. Really enjoyed this course and would 100% recommend it.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is curious about Buddhism or Eastern religions. It is well taught, the reading is helpful and manageable, and the content is very interesting!
absolutely

Yes. This is a very low-workload course that provides effective enlightenment on the foundations of a major world religion. If you'd like to understand a little more about the Buddhist canon, and don't want to increase the workload of your schedule, this course is for you. Underclassmen and upperclassmen will thrive in this course.

Yes! A super engaging and interesting class. I promise if you show up every day you will learn SO much about Buddhism. On top of that, the workload was very light and made the class even more enjoyable. Undoubtedly one of my favorite classes taken at Yale.
Yes!
YES!
Yes, I would recommend since it was very interesting
Absolutely. It is as you would expect, so if you are interested in learning about Buddhism then it is a great way to do so.
Yes! I think it's a really interesting topic that is good to know about no matter what your background may be.
Yes
Yes, this course was very engaging and provoked a lot of thought.

Yes, if you are particularly interested in understanding Buddhist culture. Otherwise, it's a complete waste of your time. If you're looking for a gut this isn't it, this should be a class you actually want to show up to and learn from as it was/the readings were quite interesting
Hands down 100%. It was my first philosophy course as a STEM major and was a great intro to the practice. I will be taking more in the future!
Yes, Whether because you are interested in Buddhist thought or need a credit, this class was interesting and I felt i learned a lot having taken it.
Yes, I found it very interesting
yes! I wouldn't take it if you have absolutely no interest in the subject matter, but it's worth the while even if you're a little curious.
Yes!! This course is an engaging and fun way to learn about Buddhism.

Definitely! I went in with no prior religious studies course and came out with a decent foundational understanding of Buddhism and its history. Very doable, most everyone regardless of major should be able to come into this class, do well, and learn a great deal.
